Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Three-Dimensional Seismometer Array at the Homestake Mine
Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the LIGO Research Support program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences and Geophysics program in the Division of Earth Sciences in the Directorate of Geosciences. Seismometer arrays are commonly used in geophysics, seismology, and engineering to study the propagation of seismic waves, detect and study their sources, and assess properties of the Earth's interior at various depths. The vast majority of seismometer arrays to date have been surface-based due to the ease of installation. This project will build and operate a dense, underground, three-dimensional array of 13 high-sensitivity broadband seismometers. The array will be located at the Homestake mine, SD, whose accessible depth of 4850 feet and vast horizontal span allow probing a 1-mile underground cube. Bringing together the existing techniques in gravitational physics and geophysics for analysis of transient and stochastic wave signals, this project is expected to give rise to qualitatively new seismic data analysis techniques. Importantly, results of these studies will also have a profound impact on the design of future underground experiments in gravitational physics, such as probes of the Equivalence Principle of Einstein's theory of relativity. Future underground gravitational-wave detectors that will observe otherwise inaccessible signatures of various astrophysical phenomena and of the Big Bang will also be designed based on the seismic noise studies conducted within this project.

This project will enable interactions between the geophysics and gravitational physics communities that would be of substantial mutual benefit. Since the future of gravity experiments is arguably underground, it is critical for the gravitational physics community to draw from the large body of knowledge in geophysics on seismic noise and seismic wave propagation. By allowing a team of physicists and geophysicists to work together on the analysis of this unique high-quality data in a mutually interesting environment, this project will lead to breakthroughs in seismic noise tomography. Such breakthroughs will have a broad range of applications and societal implications, ranging from nondestructive material testing to medical diagnosis, geophysical prospecting (detecting mineral deposits and oil), and homeland security (detecting underground cavities). The project will also educate several graduate and undergraduate students, exposing them to the frontiers of research at the intersection of the fields of geophysics and gravitational physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed and operated a 3-dimensional array of seismic stations at the Homestake mine, SD. The array spanned a volume of 1 cubic mile with 24 stations, 15 underground and 9 on the surface, each operating a high sensitivity broadband seismometer. This unique array configuration enabled detailed measurements of the seismic waves underground. The high-sensitivity of the seismometers and the exceptionally low seismic noise at the Homestake mine combined to yield very clean measurements of the seismic noise field and of various transient seismic events, including local mining explosions and earthquakes. We have also completed a series of active excitation measurements, where a seismic wave is induced either on the surface or underground with a weight drop, and the propagation of the wave is observed with the seismometer array. The entire array operated between May 2015 and September 2016, with parts of the array operating for nearly two years.

The project included development of appropriate installation techniques for underground stations. This includes pouring concrete pads directly onto the bedrock, installing a granite tile on the pad to ensure surface flatness, orienting the seismometer using a gyroscope (a compass is not reliable underground), building nested huts with insulating material to suppress local acoustic, air flow, and temperature fluctuations, and using a combination of batteries and AC power to provide continuous operation through power failures. These techniques have been demonstrated to work well, and can guide future installations of similar kind.

 

In order for the array to be successful, all stations had to be synchronized in time. The solution to this problem based on distributing the GPS signal was designed and built within the scope of this project. This solution involves acquiring the raw GPS signal at the surface, converting it to the digital signals in the optical form, and then distributing the optical signal to the underground stations. This technology has broader applications, as it is applicable in situations where GPS signal is needed underground, such as in subways, tunnels etc.

 

Data acquired by the array has already provided interesting results, and additional studies are ongoing. For example, direct measurements of the depth dependence of surface seismic (Rayleigh) waves were made (included in the Ph.D. Thesis of T. Prestegard, University of Minnesota). Similarly, the three dimensional configuration of the array allows observing teleseismic waves that arrive “from below”, including their interaction with the surface layers. These measurements are of general interest in geophysics as they directly test models for seismic wave propagation, and they also provide information about the fluctuations in the local gravitational field (known as the Newtonian noise) due to the motion of the rock.

 

The project has enabled the development of a new “radiometer” technique for analysis of seismic data, for purposes of estimating the directionality and modal content of the seismic wave field underground. The technique is based on methods used in the gravitational wave physics, modified to include different aspects of seismic wave propagation and detection. The technique was successfully tested in a series of simulations, and applications of it to the data from the Homestake array are currently ongoing.

 

The project also demonstrated the possibility of using Wiener filtering to predict seismic waveform at a given location using a limited number of seismic measurements at other locations. The method works in the frequency band 0.05 – 1 Hz, and it reaches the prediction accuracy better than 1 part in 100 at some frequencies. This technique is likely to be very useful in the future gravitational wave detector applications.

 

Finally, the measurements of the seismic wave field underground allow estimates of the Newtonian noise due to rock movements, both on the surface and at different depths underground. This information is critical for the design of future gravitational wave detectors, which may have to be built underground to minimize the contamination due to the seismic and Newtonian noise sources.
